overview.short: Spiroplasma species are helical, wall-less bacteria (Mollicutes) that lack peptidoglycan, do not Gram stain reliably, and are primarily associated with insects and plants.
overview.clinical_context: Not a typical human clinical genus; most relevance is veterinary/entomology and plant pathology (e.g., citrus diseases).

field_notes.Gram Stain: Wall-less Mollicutes do not Gram stain reliably; report as Variable/atypical if described.
field_notes.Media Grown On: Growth typically requires specialized Mollicutes media with sterols; routine Blood/MacConkey growth is not expected.
field_notes.Oxidase: Often not meaningful for Mollicutes in routine workflows; keep explicit-only handling.

key_differentiators.notes: Spiral morphology with unreliable Gram stain and wall-less biology argues against typical Gram-negative spiral rods.
Requirement for specialized sterol-containing media supports Mollicutes.
Included for schema completeness; not a primary differentiator here.

common_confusions.reason: Also Mollicutes and wall-less; overlaps in media requirements and atypical Gram stain behaviour.
Both may be described as spiral; Helicobacter is typically urease-positive and microaerophilic.

when_to_question_identification: Robust Gram-negative staining with growth on routine media suggests a different spiral/curved-rod genus.
Urease-positive microaerophilic spiral isolates suggest Helicobacter.
Strong oxidase-positive, nitrate-reducing aerobic profiles argue against Spiroplasma.

recommended_next_tests.reason: Supports visualization of helical, wall-less cells and characteristic motility.
Preferred confirmation due to atypical staining and limited biochemical resolution.
Confirms sterol-dependent growth typical of Mollicutes.
